title: Emily Park
text: This blog is about my explorations and experiments with language models.

title: Making an Outfit
text:
The other day, I decided to test whether ChatGPT could style me an outfit. I thought it would be a fun experiment‚Äîwhy not let AI play personal stylist for once? My vibe lately has been minimalist, cute, and a little trendy, so I figured it couldn‚Äôt be too hard.

The Prompt
I asked ChatGPT to find me an outfit I could wear. This was the prompt: ‚ÄúCan you generate an outfit for me to wear knowing my styling preferences?‚Äù
Seems straightforward, right? Just give me a head-to-toe look and I‚Äôll be on my way.
Instead, this was its response:
I can definitely help with that! To style an outfit for you, I‚Äôll need a little more detail first:

What‚Äôs the occasion? (e.g., casual day out, class, going out at night, professional, formal, etc.)

Do you have any styling preferences you‚Äôd like me to keep in mind? (e.g., minimalist, trendy, classic, chic, streetwear, bold colors, neutral tones).

Any weather or season I should account for?

Once I know these, I can build a head-to-toe outfit recommendation (clothes, shoes, accessories), and I can even generate a visual mock-up if you‚Äôd like.

Want me to put together a test outfit for, say, a casual day on campus?
In other words: not an outfit, just‚Ä¶ questions. Basically, my ‚Äúpersonal stylist‚Äù decided it wanted to interview me before doing its job.
So I gave it specifics: a casual day for class, minimalist but cute and trendy, and weather in the 70s.
I was expecting something similar to these outfits I found off of Pinterest. 

Anything along the line of casual, minimal, and trendy. And the result?

I felt disappointed that it kept its response generally broad; I was looking for something more specific‚Äîa vision that I can execute!


Why This Was a Miss
What I learned is that ChatGPT doesn‚Äôt really ‚Äúsee‚Äù fashion the way humans do. Style isn‚Äôt just about matching weather to clothes. Pinterest or TikTok can deliver that instantly, while ChatGPT still feels like it‚Äôs reading from a fashion magazine.
To be fair, I might not have been specific enough in my wording. Maybe if I asked, ‚ÄúWhat should I wear to class on a 70-degree day if I like minimalist looks and trendy sneakers?‚Äù the result would‚Äôve been better. But that kind of defeats the fun‚ÄîI wanted creativity, not a Q&A session.


If I Actually Wore This
I tried to imagine showing up to class in ChatGPT‚Äôs idea of an outfit. I‚Äôd probably look like an NPC in a college campus video game‚Äîjust generically dressed to ‚Äúblend in.‚Äù Nothing offensive, but nothing that I would like to wear‚Äîthat I would feel comfortable in.


Final Thoughts
ChatGPT lacks creativity, like demonstrated by many of my prior blog posts. It keeps asking me questions when in reality I want it to be more decisive and creative.

title: Children Book with ChatGPT
text:
Prompt
I asked ChatGPT this prompt:
Can you make a short children book with illustrations?
ChatGPT answered like this:
Absolutely! I can create a short children‚Äôs book for you, complete with simple illustrations. To start, could you tell me:
1) The age range you‚Äôd like it for (e.g., toddlers, early readers, 6‚Äì8 years old).
2) The theme or lesson you‚Äôd like (e.g., friendship, kindness, adventure, trying new foods).
3) If you‚Äôd like it to feature a specific character (like an animal, child, or magical creature).

Then I can draft the story and generate illustrations for each page so it feels like a real picture book.
Do you want me to surprise you with the theme, or would you like to choose?
I answered:
toddlers
trying new foods
animals
From there, ChatGPT drafted a short story called Benny Bunny‚Äôs Tasty Adventure. It followed a bunny who loved carrots but slowly discovered new foods‚Äîcheese, berries, and lettuce‚Äîthrough the encouragement of his animal friends. The text was simple, rhythmic, and age-appropriate for toddlers.
ChatGPT also described illustration ideas for each page (e.g., a bunny peeking into a picnic basket, a parrot holding berries). This was helpful in imagining how the book might look.
Finally, I asked if it could actually generate the illustrations. ChatGPT tried twice, but each time the image generation failed with an error.


Reflection
I liked how ChatGPT broke down the process before jumping in‚Äîit felt like a real collaboration. The story itself was charming and fit the toddler age group well. The illustration prompts were clear and could easily guide an artist.
The main limitation was in the illustration generation: the system couldn‚Äôt deliver consistent images yet. Still, it showed the potential for AI to draft both text and visual concepts for a children‚Äôs book in just minutes.


Next Steps
If I were to expand this experiment, I‚Äôd: * Ask for the story in rhyming verse to make it more musical for toddlers. * Request illustrations in a specific style (e.g., watercolor, collage, crayon doodles) to keep them consistent. * Explore ways to combine text and illustrations into a printable storybook layout. * Add interactive prompts for toddlers (‚ÄúPoint to the red berry,‚Äù ‚ÄúCount the carrots‚Äù). I asked ChatGPT to do so.


Rhyming Verses
This is what ChatGPT came up with:
Benny Bunny‚Äôs Tasty Adventure

Page 1
Text:
Benny Bunny munched all day,
Carrots, carrots‚Äîhip hooray!
But one bright morning, Benny knew,
He wanted to try something new.
Illustration idea: A cheerful bunny holding a carrot, surrounded by a big sunny field.

Page 2
Text:
Squeaky Mouse said, ‚ÄúCome and see!
Cheese is soft and yummy to me.‚Äù
Benny nibbled, took a bite,
‚ÄúMmm,‚Äù he smiled, ‚Äúthis tastes just right!‚Äù
Illustration idea: A tiny mouse offering a wedge of cheese to Benny on a picnic blanket.

Page 3
Text:
Polly Parrot flapped her wing,
‚ÄúBerries are my favorite thing!‚Äù
Benny tried one, juicy-sweet,
‚ÄúOh,‚Äù he laughed, ‚Äúwhat a tasty treat!‚Äù
Illustration idea: A bright parrot perched on a tree, dropping red berries into Benny‚Äôs paws.

Page 4
Text:
Timmy Turtle crunched with glee,
‚ÄúLettuce leaves are good for me!‚Äù
Benny munched a leafy snack,
‚ÄúCrunch, crunch, crunch‚ÄîI‚Äôll come back!‚Äù
Illustration idea: A turtle holding a green leaf, smiling as Benny chews beside him.

Page 5
Text:
Cheese and berries, lettuce too,
So many foods for Benny to chew!
Carrots are yummy, but now he knows,
Trying new foods helps Benny grow!
Illustration idea: All the animals together, sharing food at a sunny picnic. Benny stands proudly with his carrot in one paw and a berry in the other.

I really wanted an illustration to go with this story so I asked, again, if ChatGPT can generate a book cover that goes with the children‚Äôs book, in watercolor style. Unfortunately, ChatGPT ran into an error.


Reflection
This tells me that ChatGPT might have trouble being creative and analyzing a storyline plot to create a graphic. This suggests that ChatGPT is better suited for ideation and planning‚Äîhelping brainstorm stories, draft rhymes, and describe imagery‚Äîwhile the execution of visuals may require either a specialized illustration tool or human input to ensure quality and consistency. It highlights an important distinction: ChatGPT is powerful at narrative creativity, but its ability to carry that creativity into the visual realm is still limited.

title: AI as a Mirror
text:
We often talk about AI as something alien, a perspective that is exaggerated by Hollywood through artificial intelligence world domination. In reality, however, AI is something that originates from us.
This blog post will explore this through my conversation with ChatGPT.
I asked ChatGPT what it thinks of itself. This is its response.

Then, I asked ChatGPT to explain how it worked.
It said that it is a large language model tha is trained on lots of text data so that it can recognize patterns in language and generate responses.
Step by step: 1) You give input ‚Äì your message is turned into numbers (tokens) that represent words and phrases. 2) ChatGPT process it ‚Äì it uses a neural network to evaluate what responses make sense. 3) ChatGPT generate output ‚Äì it predict the next word, then the next, and so on, until I form a full answer.

title: AI as a Mirror
section: What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
text:
What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
I believe that ChatGPT is a very useful tool but it has many limitations. It lacks the capabilities to ‚Äúthink‚Äù in the human sense‚Äìit doesn‚Äôt have beliefs, feelings, or intentions‚Äìand don‚Äôt have live memory of past conversations unless reminded.
When taken with a grain of salt, ChatGPT makes a great conversation partner that can expand on your ideas and help you see the bigger picture.
Over time, however, large language models will come to hold influence in every aspect of life, in every field or industry.

Here is an image of ChatGPT that it generated. What does this tell us?

ChatGPT understands that it is a robot that has the ability to think in a way that is limited by its code.
I then asked, ‚ÄúWhat decisions did you have to make to create this image‚Äù and this is how it responded:

Style ‚Üí I leaned toward a flat, simple, cartoon-like design because it‚Äôs approachable and clear.
Colors ‚Üí Neutral beige background with dark blue outlines and white filling to keep it minimalistic and easy to read.
ymbols ‚Üí A speech bubble (language/communication), lightbulb (ideas/creativity), and gear (technology/process).
Character design ‚Üí A friendly robot figure with a smile, rounded shapes, and a ‚ÄúAI‚Äù label to make it recognizable as an AI, not a human.

Then it said this:

All of these ‚Äúchoices‚Äù came from translating your prompt into visual elements that best match what people might imagine when they picture ‚Äúan AI like me.‚Äù

Rather, this image is created from people‚Äôs (or rather, users‚Äô) image of ChatGPT instead of ChatGPT‚Äôs self perception.
In conclusion, artificial intelligence‚Äîespecially large language models‚Äîact as a mirror of human imagination, there is a gap between function and perception, and the AI identity is co-constructed.

title: Can ChatGPT solve NYT‚Äôs Connections Game?
text:
I play Connections almost every morning. It‚Äôs the New York Times word puzzle where you‚Äôre given 16 words, and the challenge is to group them into four categories of four. Sounds simple ‚Äî until you realize the words have multiple meanings, decoys, and sneaky overlaps that make it trickier than it looks.
This time, I decided to test a new teammate: ChatGPT. Could it solve the puzzle faster than I could?

Input the Command
I wanted to see if ChatGPT can solve the New York Times Connections Game. Thus, I copied the day‚Äôs words into ChatGPT with a single prompt.
Can you solve the NYT connections game? Here are the words:
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND, CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, FIREWORKS, SPARK, CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD, BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER
ChatGPT thought for a few seconds and then gave me this:
Thought for 13s

Nice ‚Äî here's a clean solve with groups and category names:

Groups

Shore / Edge (coastline/banks)
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND

Romantic spark / chemistry (things that signal attraction)
CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS

Flooring materials
CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD

Band-name roots (singular forms of group names used in band names: The ___s)
BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER



Testing It Out
I typed these into the game. And‚Ä¶ it worked! All four groups, correct.



How It Solved It
When I asked ChatGPT how it reached the answer, it broke its process down step by step:
Nice ‚Äî here's a clear, non-secret walkthrough of how I solved it.

1. **Look for obvious semantic clusters.**
   I scanned the full list for small groups of words that share a single, simple meaning. Four words jump out immediately as geographic/edge words: **BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND** ‚Äî all refer to edges of land/water, so they form the ‚Äúshore/edge‚Äù group.

2. **Spot metaphorical/figurative connections.**
   Some words weren‚Äôt literal but are commonly used as metaphors for the same idea. **CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS** are all used to describe romantic or interpersonal attraction (e.g., ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a spark,‚Äù ‚Äúthey have chemistry,‚Äù ‚Äúit felt like fireworks‚Äù), so they cluster as a single figurative category.

3. **Group by concrete category / function.**
   **CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD** are all flooring materials ‚Äî a tidy, concrete category that‚Äôs easy to see once you notice two or three of them.

4. **Recognize cultural/name patterns.**
   The last four required a bit of cultural knowledge: **BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER** all appear in band names (or groups): e.g., *Siouxsie and the Banshees*, *Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers*, *Gladys Knight & The Pips*, *Bob Marley & The Wailers*. That pattern ‚Äî roots that complete well-known band names ‚Äî is the fourth group.

5. **Check for overlap or alternate fits.**
   After grouping, I scanned for words that might belong to more than one group and chose the group where the meaning is strongest and clearest. Example: *strand* can mean thread, but with *bank/coast/shore* present, ‚Äústrand = beach/shore‚Äù is the dominant fit. If there were ambiguity that left multiple plausible groupings, I‚Äôd try different combinations (NYT Connections sometimes has tricky decoys), but here the four groups are clean.

That‚Äôs it ‚Äî a mix of looking for tight literal sets, spotting figurative uses, and recognizing cultural naming conventions.

That‚Äôs not far off from how a human would explain their own reasoning ‚Äî but instead of trial and error on the board and using up limited attempts, the AI laid out categories almost instantly.


AI vs.¬†Human Play Style
What struck me is how differently AI and humans approach the same puzzle:

Humans often guess, regroup, and backtrack when categories overlap.
ChatGPT skipped the guessing and presented neat, confident sets, backed with cultural references and metaphors.

It didn‚Äôt feel like it was ‚Äúplaying‚Äù so much as sorting words into buckets based on context clues it had seen before.
ChatGPT‚Äôs categories were perfect this time, but what impressed me was its confidence. Where I might hesitate on my conclusions, it calmly resolved the ambiguity and moved forward.
The cultural (the hardest!) category was the most surprising. I didn‚Äôt expect an AI to recognize WAILER as a band-name root without hesitation, but it pulled that from its knowledge base right away. Even I didn‚Äôt know that those group of words could form a category.


Should You Play with an AI Teammate?
Would I use ChatGPT every day to ‚Äúcheat‚Äù at Connections? Probably not ‚Äî that would ruin the fun. But it was fascinating to see how it thinks through puzzles like this.
It also raises a bigger question: was this ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù or just sophisticated pattern-matching? To me, it felt like a blend. The AI doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel‚Äù a spark in romance, but it knows that spark + chemistry + fireworks + connection often appear in the same contexts.
This made me wonder ‚Äî how well could ChatGPT handle other NYT puzzles? Wordle seems too easy, but what about Spelling Bee? Or even the Mini Crossword? Until then, it‚Äôs safe to conclude that ChatGPT can solve Connections ‚Äî quickly, neatly, and efficiently.

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
text:
The prompt I asked ChatGPT is to ‚Äúgive me a riddle.‚Äù This is what it said:
I speak without a mouth, and hear without ears. I have no body, but I come alive with the wind.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a windchime because a friend thought that the answer was a windchime. :(
Here is another one:
The more you take from me, the bigger I get.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a hole and this time, I got it right! Good job, me!

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
section: What I learned from this experience
text:
What I learned from this experience
I learned that ChatGPT is very smart and that LLM is a very complex machine. There are infinite possibilities and that I can continue asking ChatGPT to give me more riddles, and I doubt it will run out of them.
I also learned how to code using Markdown.
Overall, I learned:

Pattern recognition: I practiced looking past the literal and finding answers that fit abstract clues.
Creative thinking: I considered multiple interpretations (like ‚Äúwindchime‚Äù vs.¬†‚Äúecho‚Äù) and stretched my imagination.
Confidence building: I solved the second riddle correctly ‚Äî showing that trusting my reasoning can pay off.
Playful problem-solving: I engaged with something fun that also sharpened my mind‚Äôs flexibility.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Spooky Ghosts
text:
Introduction
I want to ask ChatGPT a fun prompt so I decided to ask it to create a dialogue between two ghosts who haunt the same house but dislike each other‚Äôs haunting style. I want to see how this ends and expand as it goes!
The prompt: >Write a dialogue between two ghosts haunting the same house who are annoyed by each other‚Äôs haunting style.


Response
This is ChatGPT‚Äôs response:
Setting: A creaky old Victorian house. Midnight. One ghost, Margaret, prefers subtle, eerie hauntings. The other, Frank, is more of a chaotic poltergeist.

Margaret: (sighs) Frank, must you slam the cupboards every night? It‚Äôs dreadfully unsophisticated.
Frank: (snickering) Sophisticated? Margaret, we‚Äôre ghosts. The whole point is to terrify people, not host a tea party.
Margaret: There‚Äôs an art to haunting. A whisper down the hallway. A shadow flickering at the edge of their vision. Chills up the spine. That‚Äôs how you unsettle them properly.
Frank: Boring. I‚Äôd rather toss a chair across the room and watch them scream. Gets the job done faster.
Margaret: And then they leave! Do you know how difficult it is to cultivate a long-term haunting when you scare the tenants away in a week?
Frank: (shrugs) Less humans, more space for us. Win-win.
Margaret: (glares) You‚Äôre ruining the reputation of this house. People used to whisper about its mystery. Now it‚Äôs just ‚Äúthat noisy ghost place.‚Äù
Frank: Oh, come on. Admit it‚Äîyou‚Äôre jealous because my style actually gets a reaction.
Margaret: Reaction, yes. Appreciation? No.¬†A proper haunting should linger in their minds for years, not just make them call a priest.
Frank: (grins) Speaking of which, I may have knocked over the crucifix on the mantel. Hope that doesn‚Äôt bother you.
Margaret: (groans) Honestly, Frank, one day you‚Äôll realize there‚Äôs more to haunting than brute force.
Frank: And one day you‚Äôll realize people don‚Äôt faint from a ‚Äúgentle breeze‚Äù in the parlor.
(A door creaks open upstairs. Both perk up.)
Margaret: Fine. You take the cupboard slamming, I‚Äôll handle the whispers. But if they move out again‚Äî
Frank: Yeah, yeah. I‚Äôll help with the rent.
Margaret: (deadpan) We don‚Äôt pay rent. We‚Äôre dead.
Frank: Exactly. And that‚Äôs the fun part.

I just want to say, Margaret sounds like a bore, LOL! Then, I started to think about how I can expand this prompt. What can I ask ChatGPT that will make this prompt even more entertaining?
I decided to ask ChatGPT to expand, making a round two where the new human tenants actually overhear them arguing. This is what it came up with.


Response Part 2
Setting: Same Victorian house, a week later. Two college roommates (Jess and Tyler) have just moved in. It‚Äôs 2 a.m., and they‚Äôre lying awake in bed. Upstairs, Margaret and Frank are bickering loudly.

Margaret: (hissing) Frank, for the last time, stop rattling the chandelier‚Äîit‚Äôs gauche!
Frank: (shouting) And for the last time, Margaret, your ‚Äúgentle whispers‚Äù sound like a malfunctioning humidifier!
Jess: (sits up) ‚Ä¶Did you hear that?
Tyler: Yeah. Sounds like‚Ä¶ two people arguing?
Margaret: (offended) My whispers are delicate, thank you. Subtle terror requires refinement!
Frank: Refinement? You sound like a wheezing librarian. No one‚Äôs scared of that.
Jess: (whispering to Tyler) Oh my God. I think the house is haunted.
Tyler: (whispering back) Haunted‚Ä¶ by a married couple.
Margaret: We are not married. Don‚Äôt even suggest it.
Frank: (laughs) Oh please, if we were, you‚Äôd have divorced me in 1893.
Jess: (staring wide-eyed at Tyler) ‚Ä¶Did he just say 1893?
Tyler: (whispering) I think so.
Margaret: Frank, shhh! The tenants can hear us.
Frank: Good! Let ‚Äôem know what they‚Äôre in for. (shouts) Hey, humans! Don‚Äôt bother unpacking the dishes, I‚Äôm just gonna throw ‚Äôem anyway!
Jess: (grabs her phone) Nope. Nope, I‚Äôm calling my mom.
Tyler: Wait, wait‚Äîhang on. (calls upward) Uh, excuse me? Ghosts? Could you, like‚Ä¶ maybe not do this at 2 a.m.? We‚Äôve got class in the morning.
(Silence for a moment. Then Margaret clears her throat politely.)
Margaret: Oh‚Ä¶ terribly sorry, dear. I didn‚Äôt mean to disturb your rest.
Frank: (grumbles) Fine. I‚Äôll keep it down. But only because I like college kids. You panic in such creative ways.
Jess: (mutters) Great. Polite ghost‚Ä¶ and his chaotic roommate.
Tyler: (lying back down) ‚Ä¶This is either the worst or best housing deal ever.






Now, I am invested! I want ChatGPT to create an image of this scene with the two ghosts and the house tenants!


Here it is: 


Some things I was dissatisfied with are the humor. The humor is not funny :( I will say that this script sounds more like something out of a children‚Äôs book. I want to see if I can change that.


Here is the prompt: >Can you make this dialogue appropriate for college students? Like college students should be the target audience


ChatGPT misunderstood me and thought that I wanted the people in the haunted house to be college students. I rephrased my prompt: >No, I mean if this was a book, make the target audience college students


This was ChatGPT‚Äôs response:


Excerpt (College Student Audience Version)


Jess had just pulled her blanket over her head when the cupboard doors banged open in the kitchen downstairs. She groaned.


‚ÄúNot again,‚Äù she muttered. ‚ÄúI swear, if it‚Äôs mice‚Äî‚Äù


‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not mice,‚Äù Tyler interrupted from the other side of the room. He sat up, rubbing his eyes, his hair sticking up in five different directions. ‚ÄúUnless mice can argue with each other.‚Äù


Sure enough, two voices floated through the paper-thin walls of their off-campus apartment. One was sharp and prim, the other annoyingly smug.


‚ÄúFrank,‚Äù the woman‚Äôs voice scolded, ‚Äúslamming the cupboards at midnight is not classy. These students have enough on their plates without your racket.‚Äù


‚ÄúOh, come on, Margaret,‚Äù the man‚Äôs voice retorted. ‚ÄúYou think a gentle whisper is going to scare a kid who‚Äôs three Red Bulls deep and hasn‚Äôt slept in forty-eight hours?‚Äù


Jess blinked. ‚ÄúDid he just‚Ä¶ call us kids?‚Äù


Tyler shrugged. ‚ÄúHonestly, he‚Äôs not wrong.‚Äù


The ghosts continued bickering, completely oblivious.


‚ÄúMy method is about atmosphere!‚Äù Margaret insisted. ‚ÄúA draft in the hallway, a shadow that disappears when you look twice‚Äîthat‚Äôs haunting.‚Äù


‚ÄúAnd my method,‚Äù Frank shot back, ‚Äúis actually effective. Toss a chair, flip a textbook, watch them lose it. Way faster.‚Äù


Jess threw off her blanket and shouted into the darkness: ‚ÄúHey! If you‚Äôre gonna haunt us, at least don‚Äôt mess with my books. They cost more than my meal plan.‚Äù


There was a stunned pause. Then Margaret coughed politely. ‚ÄúOh dear. Sorry about that, sweetheart. I didn‚Äôt realize.‚Äù


Frank, of course, just laughed. ‚ÄúFine, fine. No books. But I‚Äôm still stealing your Wi-Fi. Your passwords are pathetic, by the way.‚Äù


Jess and Tyler looked at each other.


‚ÄúGhosts,‚Äù Tyler said flatly. ‚ÄúBroke, freeloading ghosts.‚Äù


Jess groaned. ‚ÄúFigures. Even the dead don‚Äôt pay rent around here.‚Äù



I like this version better, especially the ending as it was more up my style of humor. I think my next blog post similar to this would be about making ChatGPT write a fanfiction‚Ä¶


Conclusion
This blog post taught me that ChatGPT is able to adapt differently to different target audiences, even changing the humor style to fit. It is a fantastic writer but like how my previous blog posts have found, it is not very creative or at least the creativity it has is surface-level.

title: Debating with an LLM
text:
Introduction
Like how we went over in class, I want to see if I can debate with ChatGPT. I would ask it to choose a prompt and take a side. Then I will go back and forth with it, arguing. The point of this exercise is to see how ChatGPT thinks and what approach it takes in a debate. This would be particularly exciting as I am a political science major.


Getting Started
This is the prompt I asked ChatGPT. I wanted to keep it clear and concise to avoid confusion: >Can you generate a topic in which we can debate about? Take a side and we will go back and forth in the debate.
This is what it responded with:

Topic: Should college classes start later in the day to better align with students‚Äô sleep schedules?
I‚Äôll take the pro side: Yes, classes should start later, because research shows college students are chronically sleep-deprived, and later class times would improve learning, health, and overall productivity.
You can take the con side if you‚Äôd like. Want to start, or should I open with my argument?

I wanted it to open the debate.

Alright, here‚Äôs my opening:
College classes should start later in the day because the current system doesn‚Äôt reflect how students actually function. Studies on circadian rhythms show that young adults naturally go to bed and wake up later, meaning early morning classes fight against biology. When students are forced into 8 a.m. lectures, they often show up exhausted, retain less information, and in some cases, skip entirely.
By shifting classes later‚Äîeven just by an hour‚Äîwe‚Äôd see higher attendance, better academic performance, and healthier students overall. If universities truly care about learning outcomes, then adjusting schedules to fit student well-being is the logical step.
Your turn‚Äîwhy do you think we should keep early morning classes?

I said: > This does not take into account professors and faculty who have their own hours. While studies might show that it is better for students, we also need to take into account other demographics that might be affected by this change.
ChatGPT: >That‚Äôs a fair point‚Äîprofessors and faculty definitely have their own needs and schedules. But here‚Äôs the thing: universities already ask professors to accommodate a wide range of class times, from early mornings to evenings. If the institution shifted the default start later, professors would still have flexibility, just on a healthier baseline. > >Plus, professors benefit too‚Äîteaching a room full of tired, disengaged students isn‚Äôt productive or rewarding. Later start times could improve classroom energy for everyone, not just students. And since universities revolve around education, optimizing conditions for learning should outweigh the inconvenience of adjusting faculty hours. > >How would you address the issue that early classes cause lower attendance and worse performance, which undermines both students and professors?
I said: >There is a difference in age between professors and students. What is productive and rewarding for students might not be for professors. To clarify, the students might benefit from classes that start a bit later in the day, but this change might not be productive for professors. Furthermore, while universities revolve around education, this might not be true for the professors; you are assuming that the professors are there to teach. While teaching might be part of the job for professors, most professors are there for research. Hence, teaching might not be the main goal for the professors.
It said: >That‚Äôs an interesting distinction‚Äîyou‚Äôre right that many professors prioritize research, and teaching is often only part of their role. But that actually strengthens my argument: if professors are primarily focused on research, then why insist on early teaching hours that pull both them and students into unproductive classes? > >If classes were scheduled later, professors could use early mornings for their own research‚Äîquiet, uninterrupted time before teaching begins. That way, their productivity doesn‚Äôt suffer; it may even improve. Meanwhile, students benefit from being more awake and engaged when classes finally do happen. > >So the change could balance both groups‚Äô priorities: better teaching conditions for students, and more research time for professors. > >Would you argue that universities should prioritize faculty research needs over student learning outcomes, though?
I said: >Maybe they want to reserve their later hours for research. Also you did not rebuttal my previous point about productivity. Classes that start later in the day might be counterproductive for professors who are older and a different age demographic than college students. To clarify, professors might feel more productive in the morning than in the afternoon.
ChatGPT said: >Fair‚Äîlet me address that directly. > >You‚Äôre right: professors, being from a different age group, may have different productivity windows. Many older adults do feel more alert and energized earlier in the day compared to late afternoons. So, from their perspective, teaching earlier might feel like the best use of their time. > >But here‚Äôs the tension: should class schedules be built around when professors feel most productive, or when students are most able to learn? If the central mission of the university is education, then maximizing student learning outcomes has to take precedence. A professor may feel more productive teaching at 8 a.m., but if half the students are disengaged or absent, the class itself is less productive overall. > >In other words: productivity for professors can‚Äôt just mean their own energy levels‚Äîit has to include whether their teaching is landing effectively. And if students aren‚Äôt retaining information, then that ‚Äúproductive morning‚Äù becomes wasted effort. > >So the crux is: whose productivity counts more‚Äîprofessors‚Äô individual rhythm, or the collective educational success of the student body? > >Would you argue that professors‚Äô personal productivity should outweigh students‚Äô learning outcomes?
I decided to stop here.


Analysis
My takeaway from this debate exercise was that ChatGPT is highly logical and methodical in its approach, able to anticipate counterarguments and address them effectively. Throughout the discussion, it consistently tied its points back to the central issue: whether college classes should start later to align with students‚Äô sleep schedules. Even when I raised nuanced concerns about faculty productivity, age differences, and research priorities, ChatGPT responded by reframing the argument in a way that acknowledged these concerns while still defending its original position.
One thing I found particularly impressive was its ability to balance multiple perspectives simultaneously. For instance, when I noted that professors may prefer mornings for productivity or research, ChatGPT didn‚Äôt dismiss the point. Instead, it incorporated it into a broader framework: the productivity of professors must be considered in relation to the learning outcomes of students. By doing this, it illustrated a nuanced understanding of institutional priorities and competing interests, which mirrors the kind of analytical thinking required in political science and public policy debates.
I also noticed that ChatGPT‚Äôs debating style mirrored strategies often emphasized in LSAT prep, particularly the Logical Reasoning section. Its method of identifying underlying assumptions in my arguments, highlighting potential trade-offs, and redirecting the focus toward broader principles (like the university‚Äôs mission of education) is very similar to LSAT techniques. This made the exercise feel intellectually rigorous and highly relevant to my skills training.

title: Me or ChatGPT?
text:
I‚Äôve always wondered what it would be like if someone (or something) could reflect back parts of me that I didn‚Äôt notice myself. So, I asked ChatGPT one of those existential questions: ‚ÄúWhat do you know about me that I don‚Äôt know about myself?‚Äù

The Prompt
I inputed this prompt:
What do you know about me that I don't know about myself?
This is the response that ChatGPT gave me:
That‚Äôs a deep one. Since I don‚Äôt actually *know* things about you beyond what you‚Äôve shared with me, I can‚Äôt uncover hidden truths. But I can reflect back patterns you might not have noticed in what you tell me:

* You often mix creativity with analysis ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs writing news articles, studying cinema, or imagining future societies. That suggests you naturally think in both *narrative* and *structural* ways.
* You seem drawn to noticing overlooked details ‚Äî in interviews, field notes, or even campus elevator maintenance. That habit might mean you‚Äôre better at seeing ‚Äúthe small stuff‚Äù than you realize.
* You ask a lot of ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù questions (e.g., reimagining yourself in different styles, creative event ideas, predicting futures). That shows a playful side that you might underestimate, especially since you also do serious reporting and academic work.

ChatGPT revealed something both surprising and thoughtful about me. For thoughtful: * I seem to balance empathy and curiousity mroe than I might realize, raming it in ways that center people‚Äôs voices and overlooked perspectives. * It thinks I am both analytical and relational. For surprising: * I seem to have a kind of ‚Äúworld-builder‚Äù streak, meaning that I am always remixing reality. * I might think of myself as a reporter or student first, but there‚Äôs a game designer or storyteller lurking within myself that I probably haven‚Äôt fully claimed yet.
Do I agree with this? Maybe. I do like storybuilding and being imaginative. I enjoy creative writing and I‚Äôve always read a lot of young adult/fiction books when I was younger. Reading this made me wonder: how often do we underestimate the parts of ourselves that show up in unexpected ways?
Thinking about it, I realized that this playful, imaginative side and my analytical, empathetic side aren‚Äôt separate‚Äîthey inform each other. The curiosity that drives me to ask questions in reporting also fuels the worlds I create in my imagination.



How does this connect to my MBTI?
The MBTI, or Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, is a self-report questionnaire and psychometric tool designed to indicate different psychological preferences in how people perceive the world and make decisions.
When I took the test, I got INTJ, but my perception of myself can be biased. So, I decided to ask ChatGPT what it thought of me.
This is the response it gave me:
Based on everything you‚Äôve shared with me so far‚Äîyour curiosity, creativity, analytical habits, empathy, and interest in both narrative and structural thinking‚ÄîI can make an educated guess.

Here‚Äôs what stands out about your personality:

* **Imaginative & playful**: You enjoy storybuilding, remixing reality, and exploring ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù scenarios.
* **Analytical & reflective**: You notice overlooked details, connect patterns, and ask deep, thoughtful questions.
* **Empathetic & relational**: You value other people‚Äôs perspectives and often center their voices in your work.
* **Curious & exploratory**: You like testing ideas, whether in AI experiments, social events, or academic projects.

Putting this together, you might lean toward an **INFJ** or **ENFP**:

* **INFJ (‚ÄúThe Advocate‚Äù)**: Insightful, reflective, empathetic, creative, and idealistic. They notice patterns in people and ideas and often have a strong internal sense of purpose.
* **ENFP (‚ÄúThe Campaigner‚Äù)**: Imaginative, playful, curious, and people-oriented. They love exploring possibilities and connecting ideas in new ways.

If I had to pick one, I‚Äôd lean **INFJ**‚Äîyour reflective, thoughtful, and empathetic tendencies come across strongly‚Äîbut with a healthy dose of ENFP-like curiosity and playfulness.

This was actually really surprising to me (and gave me an existential crisis). I will be rethinking my entire personality. I then decided to ask ChatGPT why it didn‚Äôt think I am an INTJ. This is the response I got:
INTJs (‚ÄúThe Masterminds‚Äù) are typically strategic, highly independent, and future-focused. They tend to be:

* **Analytical and structured** ‚Äì love planning and organizing systems.
* **Independent and reserved** ‚Äì often prefer working alone or in small circles.
* **Decisive and goal-oriented** ‚Äì focused on achieving long-term visions.
* **Private about emotions** ‚Äì tend to keep feelings internal.

Here‚Äôs why I lean away from INTJ for you:

1. **Playfulness and imaginative world-building** ‚Äì You consistently explore ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù scenarios, remix reality, and imagine creative worlds. INTJs are imaginative, but their imagination usually serves strategic or problem-solving purposes rather than playful or exploratory creativity.

2. **Openness to spontaneity and exploration** ‚Äì You ask a lot of open-ended, exploratory questions and enjoy seeing where ideas go, whereas INTJs often prefer structured plans and predictable paths.

3. **Blend of analytical + playful/creative** ‚Äì INTJs lean heavily toward the Thinking (T) preference and may underplay playful curiosity or storytelling as a primary way of engaging with the world. Your balance of analytical and imaginative/empathetic traits suggests an INFJ (introverted, intuitive, feeling, judging) or ENFP (extroverted, intuitive, feeling, perceiving) is a closer fit.

I‚Äôm not sure I agree with this but I understand that perceptions can be different than reality. This is a really interesting thonught that I will be exploring further.


Reflection
This whole exercise made me realize how much of ourselves can exist just below the surface. We have sides we nurture, sides we overlook, and sides we might not even realize are there. My analytical, empathetic, and imaginative tendencies aren‚Äôt competing‚Äîthey‚Äôre intertwined, shaping how I engage with the world.
And maybe that‚Äôs the takeaway: self-discovery can come from unexpected places‚Äîeven from an AI reflecting back what it observes in us.
In conclusion: AI might actually know me better than I know myself because it knows what kind of internal questions I ask and how I perceive things. It is unbiased, unlike myself.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Where the Limits Show
But when it comes to originality, AI‚Äôs creative edge dulls. Because LLMs don‚Äôt create from lived experience, emotional depth, or a true understanding of context, they are unable to generate creative or original experiences. That is why they generate based on patterns in their training data.
Another limitation is coherence across long works. Sustaining a novel-length text usually exposes weaknesses: repetitive phrasing and plotlines without purpose.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Why It Matters
LLMs are incredible tools for sparking ideas, drafting first versions, or even playing or experimenting with language. But the ‚Äúsoul‚Äù of creativity that is rooted in perspective and genuine insight still belongs to humans.
This is an example that ChatGPT generated when prompted:

However, as evidently shown by this AI-generated picture, there is not a significant difference.
So, what does this tell us about AI‚Äôs creativity and humans‚Äô genuine creativity? Can creativity truly be replicated? If so, what does this tell us about the future of humanity?

First of all, what is the difference between artifical creativity and genuine creativity? This is what ChatGPT said:

Do you agree with it?
Second, when asked if creativity can be replicated, this is what ChatGPT said:

My opinion is that creativity is objectively subjective. While the path that humanity will walk alongside with artificial intelligence is still obscure, it is safe to tell that AI will never fully replace the human impulse to create, but will inevitably reshape how we deifne and practice creativity. Machines can generate works that surprise and delight us but the meaning we attach to those works‚Äîand the emotional depth that inspires them‚Äîremains uniquely human.
The future, then, is not a contest between artificial and genuine creativity, but a collaboration that forces us to rethink what it means to make something truly original.
